conclusion: Shadows are formed when an object blocks the light source; shape and size depend on positions of light source, object, and surface.
When the light source moves further away and to the front right, shadows will generally become smaller and shift position.
Shadow A is below the cylindrical object with a small protrusion.
As the light source moves to the front right, Shadow A will shift towards the back left and become smaller.
Shadow B is directly below the small, rectangular object.
Shadow B will shift towards the back left and become smaller as the light source moves.
Shadow C is to the left and slightly behind the large, white object.
Shadow C will shift more towards the back and left and reduce in size due to the light source movement.
Shadow D is below the paper airplane-like object.
Shadow D will shift towards the back left and become smaller as the light source moves.
All shadows (A, B, C, and D) will become smaller and shift towards the back left when the light source moves to the front right.
